utterances: Well, we start off by recognizing two things, that to do very little is extremely dangerous and costly; to do very little is the most costly policy.
High carbon growth will kill itself.
First, on very high price is hydrocarbons and, secondly, on the very hostile physical environment it would create.
So that's the first part.
But the second part is to recognize the positive side of this kind of technological change.
It would set off a really dynamic process of transition of discovery where the United States would be in the lead and it will be more energy secure.
It'll be cleaner, quieter, safer and more biodiverse.
So I think we have to recognize the enormous attraction of one route - the low carbon route - and the devastating consequences of the route, the high carbon route.
Well, how much time do you estimate we have?
We really have to turn this round within a decade.
The emissions in the world, if we're to have any chance of really cutting back on these risks, we'll have to peak before 2020.
But I think that if you look at the intentions that the countries of the world have expressed, and it's been remarkable in these last weeks and months as we've moved towards Copenhagen.
You've had Japan with the new prime minister saying we will cut back by 25 percent on our emissions 1990 to 2020.
You've had China setting its targets, India setting its targets, Brazil and Indonesia, strong targets for cutting deforestation, which is a very important source of emissions.
And you had progress in the United States with the Waxman-Markey Bill moving through the House.
Then you've had Lisa Jackson's announcement that the EPA will play its part, too.
If you add all these up round the world, we're not so very far away from an agreement, which could see emissions peaking before 2020 as a world and going on down from there.
I mean, given that the Copenhagen meeting won't produce a binding treaty, what are you hoping to see come out of it?
We need two things fundamentally.
We need agreements on these targets at the level of prime minister and president.

The second thing is we have to find support from the developing world, particularly for Africa and vulnerable countries, particularly for stopping deforestation, particularly for promoting new technology, that financial support is required to help the developing world make their changes.
Nicholas Stern is the chair of the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change at the London School of Economics.
He wrote the book ""The Global Deal.
Nicholas Stern, thanks for joining us and safe travels to Copenhagen.
Coming up, putting a spin on gender roles and why the glass ceiling still keeps blacks back in corporate America.
But first let's kick things off with a couple of headlines.
Today we start in California, where the population is getting more diverse but, according to the Fresno Bee, the state's judicial bench still does not reflect that.
Lawyers, judges and Governor Schwarzenegger all admit that most judges are still white and male, but they also say that it will take more than changing the appointment process.
A statewide committee is looking at the reason why only four percent of the state's judges are black, with just six percent Hispanic and another 4.4 percent Asian.
Education and interest were cited as possible reasons.
And our next headline deals with the Congressional Black Caucus, which lost one of its founding members this week - Parren Mitchell of Baltimore, who died of a stroke on Monday.
He was 85.
The caucus also lost a standing member just last month with the death of California Congresswoman Juanita Millender-McDonald.

That seat is set for a special election a few weeks from now and is in danger of being lost to the CBC because of a contentious race between two black candidates, including her daughter, who are expected to split the vote and open the door for a third candidate who is Latina.
On top of that, the CBC is also caught in another battle over its upcoming presidential debate.

Last week, a spokesman from New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson's office said he would not be participating in the September debates, which are co-sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus and Fox News.
And then, shortly after, the spokesperson retracted the statement and said Richardson was still unsure about making an appearance.
So far, Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and John Edwards have all decided not to participate in the debate.
Edward is saying his reasoning is because Fox News, in his words, is a biased news operation.
Senator Joe Biden has confirmed, though, that he will appear.
Maybe Alaska is having trouble luring presidential candidates, but Iowa?
They can't get rid of them.
And right about now some residents are more than ready to see the candidates, their staffers and all those pesky reporter types go away.
A pair of Iowans, Jason Walsmith of the band the Nadas, and Kyle Munson of the Des Moines Register, wrote a little ditty, now available on YouTube.
It's called ""The Caucus Lament.
(Singing) Get outta our town.
Get out of my face.
You barged into our home with your political race.
Jason Walsmith and Kyle Munson join us now from Des Moines.
Hi, guys.
Hello.
Hello.
How are you doing?
So what's the big deal here?
Why are you so sick of everybody there in your town?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Oh, I don't know.
It's totally a tongue-in-cheek thing, you know.
We like visitors.
I'm just tired of the commercials.
The commercials?
How bad have they gotten?
I don't think you can turn on a TV without seeing a whole string of political ads.
Yeah.
This is Kyle.

And you assume that every other phone call is a political, you know, either an invite to an actual event from a live person or a recording of the candidate or one of their, you know, legislative or, you know, elected friends.
So it really does go on.
They just want a moment of your time.
Just a moment.
You guys write in your song that the restaurants are full, the hotels are all booked, but you know, think about it.
They're filled with presidential candidates.
Shouldn't you guys consider yourself lucky that you have the chance to meet some of these people face to face?
Not everyone gets that.
Yeah.
This is Kyle.
Yeah, we love the spotlight and the chance to really kind of go through this process for the rest of the nation.
So yeah, we take that seriously.
And it's true, in one sense we wouldn't have any other way, but it kind of started down this road because, well, there is first in the nation fatigue, you know?
So you can feel lucky and get a little soured on the whole process I think all at the same time.

But you know, we've certainly seen the whole, you know, the full range of celebrity endorsements, whether, you know, as we mention in the song, whether it's Oprah with Obama or Kevin Bacon here, you know, we've seen - John Mellencamp is going to come play for Edwards on the eve of the caucuses.
Jackson Brown played at Roosevelt High School.
Yeah.
With Bonnie Raitt.
Yeah.
Seriously, guys, you don't get these kinds of acts anywhere else in the Midwest.
I think you should be a little bit more grateful.
Yeah, no...
(Soundbite of laughter)
You know what?
Thanks - thank you for opening our eyes.
You're right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'm sorry.
We're already starting to right the next song, which, you know, which - in February - it's going to be please come back, we're bored.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So come Friday, January 4th, caucuses are over.
Everybody's gone home.
What are your big plans once your state has been hopefully vacated?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Friday, January 4th, I'll be in Shanghai, China.
Yeah, well - and this is Kyle.
You know, and being in the news business, I'm still skeptical that the vote will be decided by then.
So you know, the most historic, you know, process in 50 years, and it's so close.
You know, I expect I'll probably still be in the newsroom trying to, you know, file stories and count all the votes.
So...
Kyle Munson and Jason Walsmith are the Iowans who wrote ""Caucus Lament.
(Singing) Get outta our town.
Get out of my face.
You barged into my home with your political race.
Eventually, YouTube and all the other big video sites will start offering their own HD content because Americans already are watching billions of videos online.
With that many eyeballs roaming the online video landscape, it's inevitable that any technical advance by one video service will be copied before long by all its competitors.
For now, though, Vimeo - which has about 275,000 users - is one of the most unique online video services on the Web.
It offers aspiring directors a chance to make their projects shine, and it gives you one more reason to justify buying that fancy, new high-definition camcorder you've had your eye on.
(Soundbite of archived video)
